awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology, which gives us the ability to manipulate and interrogate physical systems on a length scale of nanometers to microns, has become pervasive in many fields of scientific inquiry and engineering. Access to basic nanotechnology tools has therefore become increasingly important, not only for so-called nanotechnologists but for scientists and engineers from many academic disciplines and from industry.  The Montana Nanotechnology Facility (MONT), a NNCI site at Montana State University, promotes discovery, education and outreach related to nanotechnology by providing access to shared-use instruments, expert training on their safe and effective use, and broad-based education about nanoscale science and technology for learners at all levels who come from diverse communities. The MONT site serves both regional users in the northern Rocky Mountains and Great Plains and users from across the U.S. who need the specific expertise and equipment found at Montana State University. Those users are pursuing diverse objectives related to advances in health care diagnostics and surgical solutions, sources of clean energy, remediation strategies for contaminated soils, and technologies related to optical telecommunications, imaging systems and advanced computing. By enhancing our service to external users and building on its unique fabrication and characterization strengths MONT will help to meet a national need for access to nanotechnology, for training of the workforce that will develop the nanotechnology of the future, and for education and outreach that engages and informs students and teachers from kindergarten to graduate school, industrial users and the general public.

MONT helps meet the growing need faced by regional and national researchers for access to nanofabrication tools and processes at the interdisciplinary frontiers, with local expertise related to microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and micro-opto-electromechanical systems (MOEMS), microfluidics, nanostructured materials with unique optical, mechanical or thermal properties, ceramic materials, bio-inspired and bio-derived nanostructures, and bacteria or bacterial biofilms incorporated into micro- or nano-engineered substrates. he goals of the MONT site are: (i) to increase the number of external users served; (ii) to increase the collective research output of MONT users; (iii) to enhance the MONT site's capabilities in the areas of its research strengths through heavily leveraged capital investment; and (iv) to create best-in-class educational opportunities for facility users, STEM educators and the general public. These goals are accomplished through specific initiatives that will add laboratory personnel to enhance training, assistance and advocacy for external users, establish a user grant program for external users to help address costs of facility use as well as local housing, invest in new tools and capabilities, and expand both on-site and web-based instructional and outreach activities related to nano-fabrication, nano-characterization and the ethics and societal impacts of nanotechnology. The project specifically improves access to nanotechnology infrastructure in the northern Rockies/Great Plains region, and it promotes discovery, education and outreach in emerging fields where nanotechnology is impacting the life sciences, health care, energy, the environment, and a number of important technology sectors.

por.por_cntn:
The Montana Nanotechnology (MONT) Facility promotes discovery, education and outreach related to nanotechnology by providing training and access to specialized equipment, interaction with experts in the related fields, and broad-based education about nanoscale science and technology for learners at all levels who come from diverse communities.

The users of the MONT Facility comprise a vibrant community of scientists and engineers who use nanotechnology as a tool, creating a fertile environment for new ideas and different ways of approaching problems.

MONT’s academic researchers addressed fundamental research questions and pursued very useful applications in areas such as biofouling, bioremediation, nanostructured materials for high-temperature or corrosive environments and optical microdevices, novel approaches to Alzheimer’s disease, innovative new building materials, and so much more. Access to MONT facilities enabled researchers to secure funding for impactful research from both the US government and private foundations.

With the use of MONT facilities, our private sector users have commercialized many products such as optical and photonic devices, medical diagnostic devices and more, impacting areas of food safety, water safety, defense, and homeland security. They are creating nanotech devices and processes for better products for the consumer, while creating jobs for the regional economy.

The MONT Facility has decades of experience in providing shared-use nanofabrication and characterization capabilities. With this project, we enhanced our services to external users to help meet the growing need faced by local, regional and national researchers for access to nanofabrication tools and processes at the interdisciplinary frontiers.

Usage has grown steadily since the project inception. In 2020 we hosted 169 unique users working on the projects of more than 60 principal investigators. These users came from both academia (~70%) and industry (~30%).  We also educated hundreds of k-12 students and teachers about the nano-world, and our facilities were used by hundreds of university students learning both the science and application of nanotechnology.

The specific goals of this project were:

1)     To increase the number of external users served, thereby enhancing the impact of the specialized and expensive equipment housed in university nanotechnology facilities.

Outcome: We met an aggressive 20% annual growth target, achieving an average annual growth rate of 22% over the first 4 years of this effort (year 5 showed no growth, mainly due to the closures of facilities due to the COVID-19 pandemic).  MONT provided facility access to 52 different companies during this time.

2)     To increase the research output of MONT users.

Outcome: We exceeded our 5-year target of 100% increase, with the number of research products increasing from 31 in year 1 to 141 in year 4, and 83 in a COVID-impacted year 5.  During the project, facility users published over 250 journal articles, gave more than 200 conference papers and presentations, wrote 11 book chapters and filed 16 patents.

3)     To enhance the MONT Facility capabilities in the areas of our research strengths through capital investment.

Outcome: MONT placed equipment valued at more than $3M, through a combination of federal, state and private foundation funding. Researchers have benefitted tremendously from the facility upgrades made during this award, with new capabilities for nanofabrication including the deposition and characterization of thin films, wafer etching, cleaning and bonding, and many specialized tools for nanometer resolution imaging and compositional analysis.

4)     To create ‘best in class’ educational opportunities for facility users, STEM educators and the general public.

Outcome: MONT created or participated in on-site and web-based education for K-12 teachers, student researchers, private sector researchers, and K-gray public events. We significantly expanded our web teaching resources, particularly in nano-geo sciences. We formed a partnership with Native American serving Salish Kootenai College to increase access to nanoscience learning and tools, and we engaged in numerous community outreach events at schools and other venues to promote awareness of the importance of nanotechnology.

Broader Impacts

The MONT Facility has a tremendous impact on a diverse group of students, teachers and the general public.

  • One third of our trained users are undergraduates working on independent research projects. Many of the students go on to work in nanotechnology industries after graduation. Others continue with advanced graduate study.
  • Fully 40% of our student users, students who have found a niche in nanotechnology, are women.
  • More than 70 science teachers from around the country have built photovoltaic solar cells in the MONT Facility, and then taken them back to their classrooms for hands-on learning.
  • Lab-based short courses, webinars, training materials and online collections of educational resources were developed for local MONT users and the broader NNCI network.
  • Our outreach activities engaged the general public from pre-school ages to adults.

Finally, there is the aggregate impact on society of the myriad research projects enabled by the MONT Facility. This may be the most important impact of all.
